There are several criticisms of Augustine's views on sexuality and marriage. One major critique is that his views are patriarchal and limit the agency and autonomy of women. Augustine views women primarily as sexual objects and prohibits them from seeking pleasure in sexual relationships. Additionally, his teachings on original sin condemn sexual desire as inherently sinful and evil, which can lead to shame and guilt for those who experience sexual desire.

Feminist and queer theologians have challenged Augustine's views on sexuality and marriage by emphasizing the importance of consent, mutuality, and equality in sexual relationships. They argue that women should have the right to explore and enjoy their sexuality and that same-sex relationships can be legitimate expressions of love and commitment. Furthermore, they critique the Christian tradition's focus on procreation as the primary purpose of marriage, arguing that intimacy and companionship are also important aspects of marital relationships.

Overall, feminist and queer theologians have challenged Augustine's views on sexuality and marriage by advocating for a more inclusive and compassionate approach to sexuality that values the dignity and agency of all individuals.
